intro: Lupinus silvicola, commonly known as the woodland lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories. The plant features compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces spikes of blue to purple flowers. Lupinus silvicola is part of the legume family, Fabaceae, and has the ability to fix nitrogen through symbiotic relationships with soil bacteria. Its growth habit and floral structure make it an important component of native plant communities.
